purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of the data that specifies tasks. The task specifications can then be referenced from schedules and in recording activities that have been undertaken.
Tasks may have the following characteristics:

ul.li: A Task is the combination of something to be achieved and, optionally, a way to achieve it. The same result can be achieved through more than one method;
A Task can be defined as simple text or as as a processible structure using repeats, sequences and decision points;
A Task can be associated with pre and post states.

purpose.p: The following are not enabled by directly this module alone but are enabled by modules that use this module:

ul.li: A Task can be associated with the resources required to do it. The quantity of resource and the probability that it is needed can be specified;
A resource may optionally be linked to specific stages within a task as well as to the overall task;
The output from a task can be specified, with quantities and probabilities of occurrence.

inscope.li: the specification of a task as a sequence of instructions encoded as text;
the specification of a task as a structured set of instructions;
the association of pre-conditions to a task or a stage within a task;
the association of post-conditions to a task or a stage within a task;

outscope.li: the identification and detailed description of resources required by tasks;
the history of execution of tasks and the corresponding use of resources;
the association of predicted resource requirements to a task;
the association of predicted inputs or resources to a task;
the association of predicted outputs from a task;
the things to which a task may be assigned;
the association of task to the context in which it was generated or is to be applied.

uof.name: Task_specification
uof.description:
The Task_specification UoF enables the specification of tasks and task methods. The method to be followed may be specified as a sequence of stages, including advisory stages, as repeating and conditional stages. A task may invoke another task as a stage.
A task may be related to states that it requires or generates.
